sen.j: 日本舞踊（にほんぶよう）は、Japanese danceの和訳、つまり日本のダンスの総称である。
sen.e: Nihon Buyo is Japanese translation of Japanese dance and it is a generic term for dances in Japan.
Nihon Buyo is Japanese translation of Japanese dance and it is a generic term for dances in Japan.
Nihon Buyo is Japanese translation of Japanese dance and it is a generic term for dances in Japan.

sen.j: そもそも舞踊とは、坪内逍遥と福地源一郎による造語で、日本の伝統的なダンスである舞（まい）と踊（おどり）をくっつけたもの。
sen.e: Buyo is originally a coined word created by Shoyo TSUBOUCHI and Genichiro FUKUCHI by merging two terms referring to Japanese dances 'mai (a formal traditional Japanese dance)' and 'odori (dancing or dance).'

Buyo is originally a coined word created by Shoyo TSUBOUCHI and Genichiro FUKUCHI by merging two terms referring to Japanese dances 'mai (a formal traditional Japanese dance)' and 'odori (dancing or dance).'

Buyo is originally a coined word created by Shoyo TSUBOUCHI and Genichiro FUKUCHI by merging two terms referring to Japanese dances 'mai (a formal traditional Japanese dance)' and 'odori (dancing or dance).'

sen.j: 逍遥の『新楽劇論』（明治37年）で使われてから広く用いられるようになった。
sen.e: It has become a commonly used term after it was introduced in "Shin Gakugekiron (New Musical Drama Theory)" written by Shoyo in 1904.
It has become a commonly used term after it was introduced in "Shin Gakugekiron (New Musical Drama Theory)" written by Shoyo in 1904.
It has become a commonly used term after it was introduced in "Shin Gakugekiron" (New Musical Drama Theory) written by Shoyo in 1904.
sen.cmt: 書物の説明を"のそとへ

sen.j: 近年、日本舞踊の国際化に伴い欧米諸国やアジアにも Nihon Buyo という呼称が定着しつつある。
sen.e: In recent years, as Japanese dance has gone international, the term Nihon Buyo is establishing itself in the Western countries and the Asian region.
In recent years, as Japanese dance has gone international, the term Nihon Buyo is establishing itself in the Western countries and the Asian region.
In recent years, as Japanese dance has gone international, the term Nihon Buyo is establishing itself in the Western countries and the Asian region.

sen.j: 舞（まい、旧かな表記まひ）とは、歌や音楽に合わせて、すり足などで舞台を回るもの。
sen.e: Mai (or Mahi as written in old kana) refers to a performing art whereby dancers move around the stage while performing various choreographed movements including walking in suriashi (sliding steps) to the accompaniment of songs and music.
sen.cmt: 「すり足」は 'sliding steps' に訂正。books.google.co.jp/books?isbn=0486406458 原文はかなり抽象的な表現で、そのまま英訳をしますと読者にとって難解な内容になる恐れがありますので、それを避けるために補足してあります。
sen.e: Mai (or Mahi as written in old kana) refers to a performing art whereby dancers move around the stage while performing various choreographed movements including walking in suriashi (sliding steps) to the accompaniment of songs and music.

Mai ("まい", or "まひ" as written in old kana) refers to a performing art whereby dancers move around the stage while performing various choreographed movements including walking in suriashi (sliding steps) to the accompaniment of songs and music.
sen.cmt: (or Mahi as written in old kana)発音は同じで表記の話題なので不要、もしくは→("まい", or "まひ" as written in old kana)

sen.j: 神楽・舞楽・白拍子・延年・曲舞・幸若舞・能楽・上方舞などが当たる。
sen.e: Mai includes kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines), bugaku (music accompanying traditional Japanese Court dances), shirabyoshi (popular music with dance in Heian and Kamakura Era), ennen (ennenmai or music with dance performed in temples mainly in Kamakura and Muromachi Era), kusemai (music and dance with a fan along with a tsuzumi or music and dance with a fan along with a Japanese hand drum), kowakamai (story-telling with a simple dance), Noh play (a Noh dance) and kamigatamai (a dance developed in Kyoto and Osaka).

Mai includes kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines), bugaku (music accompanying traditional Japanese Court dances), shirabyoshi (popular music with dance in Heian and Kamakura Era), ennen (ennenmai or music with dance performed in temples mainly in Kamakura and Muromachi Era), kusemai (music and dance with a fan along with a tsuzumi or music and dance with a fan along with a Japanese hand drum), kowakamai (story-telling with a simple dance), Noh play (a Noh dance) and kamigatamai (a dance developed in Kyoto and Osaka).

Mai includes kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines), bugaku (music accompanying traditional Japanese Court dances), shirabyoshi (popular music with dance in Heian and Kamakura Era), ennen (ennenmai or music with dance performed in temples mainly in Kamakura and Muromachi Era), kusemai (music and dance with a fan along with a tsuzumi or music and dance with a fan along with a Japanese hand drum), kowakamai (story-telling with a simple dance), Noh play (a Noh dance) and kamigatamai (a dance developed in Kyoto and Osaka).

sen.j: 踊り（おどり、旧かな表記をどり）とは、歌や音楽に合わせて、足を踏み鳴らしリズムに乗った手振り・身振りをするもの。
sen.e: Odori (wodori as written in old kana) refers to a dance whereby dancers stamp their feet and moving their hands and bodies to the rhythm of the accompaniment song and music.
Odori (wodori as written in old kana) refers to a dance whereby dancers stamp their feet and moving their hands and bodies to the rhythm of the accompaniment song and music.
Odori ("おどり", or "をどり" as written in old kana) refers to a dance whereby dancers stamp their feet and moving their hands and bodies to the rhythm of the accompaniment song and music.
sen.cmt: (wodori as written in old kana)発音は同じで表記の話題なので不要、もしくは→("おどり", or "をどり" as written in old kana)

sen.j: 念仏踊り・盆踊りなどが当たる。
sen.e: It corresponds to nenbutsu-odori (a dance with a prayer (an invocation) to (the) Buddha) and Bon dancing (the Bon festival dance).
It corresponds to nenbutsu-odori (a dance with a prayer (an invocation) to (the) Buddha) and Bon dancing (the Bon festival dance).
It corresponds to nenbutsu-odori (a dance with a prayer (an invocation) to (the) Buddha) and Bon dancing (the Bon festival dance).

sen.j: 以下のうち、一般に「日本舞踊」とは歌舞伎舞踊・上方舞を指す。
sen.e: Of the following, 'Nihon Buyo' is generally referred to as the Kabuki buyo (Kabuki is a type of traditional Japanese drama which follows highly-stylized forms and takes up stories with popular appeal) and Kamigata Mai (a type of dance which was popular in the Kansai region in the mid to late Edo Period).

Of the following, 'Nihon Buyo' is generally referred to as the Kabuki buyo (Kabuki is a type of traditional Japanese drama which follows highly-stylized forms and takes up stories with popular appeal) and Kamigata Mai (a type of dance which was popular in the Kansai region in the mid to late Edo Period).

Of the following, 'Nihon Buyo' is generally referred to as the Kabuki buyo (Kabuki is a type of traditional Japanese drama which follows highly-stylized forms and takes up stories with popular appeal) and Kamigata Mai (a type of dance which was popular in the Kansai region in the mid to late Edo Period).

sen.e: Mai performed at festivals of the people

sen.j: 現在では、約200流派以上が存在している。
sen.e: Approximately 200 schools exist today.

sen.j: その中でも5大流派と呼ばれているのは下記の5氏。
sen.e: Of these, the following are referred to as the 5 major schools.
Of these, the following are referred to as the 5 major schools.

sen.j: 花柳流（はなやぎりゅう）
sen.e: The Hanayagi School
The Hanayagi School
The Hanayagi School

sen.j: 1849年、花柳壽輔が創始。
sen.e: Founded by Jusuke HANAYAGI in 1849.
Founded by Jusuke HANAYAGI in 1849.
Founded by Jusuke HANAYAGI in 1849.

sen.j: 花柳壽輔は4世西川扇藏に学び、歌舞伎舞踊の振付師として重きをなした。
sen.e: Jusuke HANAYAGI studied under Senzo NISHIKAWA IV and played an important role as a choreographer of the Kabuki buyo.
Jusuke HANAYAGI studied under Senzo NISHIKAWA IV and played an important role as a choreographer of the Kabuki buyo.
Jusuke HANAYAGI studied under Senzo NISHIKAWA IV and played an important role as a choreographer of the Kabuki buyo.

sen.j: 最初は家庭の子女の舞踊として浸透したが、今は組織力の強さで最大の流派（名取数約15000名）となっている。
sen.e: The Hanayagi School initially became popular as the buyo as a culture lesson for women and young girls from ordinary families but, thanks to its strong organizational skills, it has grown to the largest school (having approximately 15,000 accredited masters or persons having a diploma to teach buyo) in Japan.

sen.j: 当代は4代目。
sen.e: The present head of the school is the fourth generation.
The present head of the school is the fourth generation.

sen.j: 藤間流（ふじまりゅう）
sen.e: The Fujima School
The Fujima School

sen.j: 藤間勘兵衛が宝永年間に創始。
sen.e: Founded by Kanbe FUJIMA in early 1700's.
Founded by Kanbe FUJIMA in early 1700's.
Founded by Kanbe FUJIMA in early 1700's.

sen.j: 茅場町の藤間勘十郎家・浜町の藤間勘右衛門家に分かれる。
sen.e: The school has been branched into 2 families including the Kanjuro Fujima family of Kayaba-cho Town and the Kanemon Fujima family of Hama-cho Town.
The school has branched into 2 families including the Kanjuro Fujima family of Kayaba-cho Town and the Kanemon Fujima family of Hama-cho Town.
The school has branched into 2 families including the Kanjuro FUJIMA family of Kayaba-cho Town and the Kanemon FUJIMA family of Hama-cho Town.

sen.j: 3世藤間勘右衛門が松本流を派生させる。
sen.e: Kanemon FUJIMA III established the derivative Matsumoto School.
Kanemon FUJIMA III established the derivative Matsumoto School.

sen.j: 若柳流（わかやぎりゅう）
sen.e: The Wakayagi School

sen.j: 初世花柳壽輔の門から出た花柳芳松が、1893年に若柳吉松(のち寿童)と改名して創始。
sen.e: Yoshimatsu HANAYAGI from the school of Jusuke HANAYAGI I assuming the new name of Yoshimatsu (subsequently Judo) WAKAYAGI founded the Wakayagi School in 1893.

sen.j: 花柳界で発展したため、手振りが多く、品のある舞踊である。
sen.e: Since it developed in the pleasure quarters, it is a graceful form of buyo with intricate hand and arm movements.

sen.j: 元禄時代に始まり、2世西川扇藏が確立した。
sen.e: It began in the Genroku Era between the late 1600's and the beginning of 1700's and was established by Senzo NISHIKWA II.

sen.j: 三百年の歴史を有し、当代は10代目である。
sen.e: This school has a 300 year-history and the present head of the school is the 10th generation.

sen.j: 坂東三津五郎 (3代目)を祖とする。
sen.e: The head of the school is Mitsugoro BANDO III.
The head of the school is Mitsugoro BANDO III.

sen.j: 3代は初代の子で、舞踊の名手として化政文化期の代表的俳優だった。
sen.e: Mitsugoro BANDO III is a son of the Mitsugoro BANDO I who was a brilliant dancer and a leading actress of the Kasei culture era.
